    Heat Shock Protein 90 Inhibitors: An Update on Achievements, Challenges, and Future Directions

    • Li Li
      Li Li
      State Key Laboratory of Natural Medicines, and Jiang Su Key Laboratory of Drug Design and Optimization, China Pharmaceutical University, Nanjing 210009, China
      Department of Medicinal Chemistry, School of Pharmacy, China Pharmaceutical University, Nanjing 210009, China

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Hsp90 is one of the most important chaperones involved in regulating the maturation of more than 300 client proteins, many of which are closely associated with refractory diseases, including cancer, neurodegenerative diseases, and viral infections. Clinical Hsp90 inhibitors bind to the ATP pocket in the N-terminal domain of Hsp90 and subsequently suppress the ATPase activity of Hsp90. Recently, with the increased understanding of the discrepancies in the isoforms of Hsp90 and the modes of Hsp90-co-chaperone-client complex interactions, some new strategies for Hsp90 inhibition have emerged. Novel Hsp90 inhibitors that offer selective suppression of Hsp90 isoforms or specific disruption of Hsp90-co-chaperone protein–protein interactions are expected to show with satisfactory efficacy and safety profiles. This review summarizes the recent progress in Hsp90 inhibitors. Additionally, Hsp90 inhibitory strategies are emphasized in this review.

    SPECIAL ISSUE

    This article is part of the Women in Medicinal Chemistry special issue.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Many refractory diseases, such as malignancies and neurodegenerative disorders, pose a tremendous threat to human health due to their complicated pathogenesis, which includes the abnormal expression of many proteins and aberrant signal transduction. Thus, the simultaneous regulation of signaling pathways relevant to disease, especially in neoplasia, has emerged as a promising chemotherapeutic approach.(1) Hsp90, an essential and evolutionarily conserved molecular chaperone in eukaryotes, demonstrates increased expression during cellular stress to mitigate cell damage.(2) This biological process is termed the heat shock response (HSR). Hsp90 achieves its regulatory function by mediating the folding and maturation of more than 300 client proteins via the participation of co-chaperones.(3) Among these client proteins, numerous downstream substrates of Hsp90 are closely associated with hallmarks of cancer.(4) More than 20 co-chaperones are required for the stabilization of a specific conformation of Hsp90 and/or recruitment of the corresponding client proteins.(5) In normal metabolism, Hsp90 is a primary master regulator of gene expression, proliferation, and the cell cycle. In contrast, dysregulation of Hsp90 causes dysregulation of cell homeostasis and overexpression of client proteins, which are inducible factors for the development of refractory diseases. In summary, Hsp90 is not only required for the maturation of downstream substrates, including tyrosine kinase receptors (such as EGFR and Her2), signal transduction proteins (such as Braf and Akt), cell cycle regulatory proteins (Cdk4/6), and antiapoptotic proteins (Bcl-2),(6) but is also critical for the formation of a feedback loop with upstream transcriptional regulators.(7) Thus, Hsp90 plays a crucial role in cellular signal transduction networks, and its upregulation could lead to dysregulated expression of numerous proteins, especially in the development of cancer.
    As Hsp90 is a significant target in cancer, Hsp90 inhibitors have attracted intense research attention. Many groups and companies have studied Hsp90 inhibitors, and a great deal of progress has been made over the past few decades. To date, several Hsp90 inhibitors have entered clinical trials for various refractory cancers and are summarized in section 5.1. However, most of these trials have been terminated in different clinical phases due to lack of efficacy and inevitable off-target effects, including hepatotoxicity and ocular toxicity.(8) Consequently, numerous studies have been performed to explore novel Hsp90 inhibitors aimed at avoiding adverse effects and drug resistance. The inhibitory strategies of Hsp90 are worthy of intense study in the field of drug design. Therefore, analysis of the deficiencies of Hsp90 inhibitors and a discussion of the prospects of Hsp90-targeted therapies are necessary. Numerous compelling reviews have summarized the mechanistic development and performance of Hsp90 inhibitors in cancer therapy. Significant progress has been made regarding multiple aspects of this topic. Thus, it is necessary to review recent progress, summarizing different inhibition strategies and discussing future prospects and challenges. In this review, we briefly summarize the discovery of Hsp90 N-terminal inhibitors, focus on novel inhibitory strategies targeting Hsp90, and discuss future opportunities and challenges related to Hsp90 inhibition. Additionally, the causes of drug resistance and the toxicity of current inhibitors are highlighted to provide references for the development of Hsp90 inhibitors.

    2. Structure and Biological Functions of Hsp90

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Hsp90 is thought to be the most abundant heat shock protein, and four isoforms can be categorized in mammalian cells: Hsp90α and Hsp90β in the cytosol, Grp94 in the endoplasmic reticulum, and Trap1 in mitochondria (Figure 1). The N-terminal domain of Hsp90 (Hsp90N) is required for binding with ATP and co-chaperones.(9) A mitochondrial signal sequence is located in the N-terminus of Trap1. Compared with the sequence of Hsp90α/β, the sequence of Grp94 includes five extra residues (QEDGQ) in the N-terminal ATP pocket. The charged linker in Hsp90α/β is responsible for nuclear localization but possesses calcium activity in Grp94. Unfolded client proteins are assembled on the middle domain of Hsp90 (Hsp90M). The C-terminal domain of Hsp90α/β ends with a highly conserved pentapeptide, MEEVD. This peptide is specialized to interact with co-chaperones containing tetratricopeptide repeats (TPRs).(10) Compared with Hsp90α/β, the sequence of KDEL in the C-terminal domain of Grp94 is responsible for endoplasmic reticulum localization.(11) In addition, another ATP binding pocket has been reported to be located in the C-terminal domain.(12)
    In general, Hsp90 acts as a clamp during the formation of homodimers. The clamp is anchored by dimerization of the C-terminus, and the jaw is composed of the N-terminal domains. ATP hydrolysis and co-chaperones binding in the N-terminus control the open or closed state of the clamp.(13) Co-chaperones are endowed with two main functions in the Hsp90 chaperone cycle, and these functions may overlap (Table 1). Co-chaperones are involved in regulating the conformational switch of the clamp through inhibition or promotion of ATP hydrolysis. The other primary function of co-chaperones is required for the recruitment of a subset of client proteins to assemble on Hsp90; importantly, some of these proteins specifically recognize certain clients. The selectivity mechanism may occur by the direct interaction of co-chaperones with specific clients. Co-chaperones interact with the different domains of Hsp90. TPR co-chaperones interact with the conserved MEEVD sequence in Hsp90C via their characteristic TPR domain. The functions and interaction domains of Hsp90-dependent co-chaperones are shown in Table 1.
    Table 1. Overview of the Functions and Interaction Domains of Hsp90-Dependent Co-chaperones
    co-chaperonesinteraction domains in co-chaperoneinteraction domains in Hsp90client selectivityeffect on the conformation of Hsp90
    Sti1/HopTPRCnon-specific–
    Tah1TPRCclients involved in assembling small nuclear ribonucleoprotein–
    Cdc37M, CN, Mkinasestabilizes the open state
    Sgt1CSNnucleotide-binding leucine-rich repeat receptors–
    Aha1N, CN, M–promotes the closed state
    Pp5/Ppt1TPRC–promotes the closed state
    FKBP51/FKBP52 Cyp40TPRCsteroid receptors kinases–
    p23/Sba1NN–promotes the closed state
    In normal cells, Hsp90 is a vital regulator of the cell cycle, proliferation, signal transduction, and transcriptional regulation.(14) However, under stress conditions, Hsp90 induction is markedly upregulated to promote the misfolding and overexpression of client proteins.(15) Client proteins of Hsp90 are summarized on the Picard Lab Web site (https://www.picard.ch/downloads/Hsp90interactors.pdf). Hsp90α/β are extremely similar in regulating client proteins such as Tau,(16) Cdk4/6, Her2, EGFR, and Akt.(17) In contrast, Grp94 primarily modulates Toll-like receptors (TLRs), integrins, Her2, and LRP6.(18) The Wnt/β-catenin signaling pathway is crucial for immune regulation and oncogenesis. However, this signaling pathway was blocked in Grp94 knockout (Grp94-KO) multiple myeloma cell lines.(19) These results suggest that Grp94 inhibition may be involved in immune disease(20) and cancer. In addition, knockdown of Trap1 in esophageal cancer cell lines induced reactive oxygen species (ROS) accumulation and cell cycle arrest.(21) Furthermore, Trap1-KO esophageal cancer cell lines exhibited restored proliferation and cell apoptosis after re-expression of Trap1.(21) Briefly, Hsp90 upregulation results in (i) excessive aggregation of client proteins; (ii) promotion of cell proliferation and angiogenesis; (iii) acceleration of the cell cycle; and (iv) promotion of cell migration and invasion.

    3. Regulatory Mechanism of Hsp90 Chaperones

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The Hsp90 chaperone cycle can be divided into the following steps (Figure 2). Initially, Hsp70 is responsible for identifying unfolded substrates, which are delivered to Hsp90 via stress-inducible 1/Hsp70–Hsp90 organizing protein (Sti1/HOP).(22) By this process, unfolded substrates are recognized by co-chaperones and loaded onto Hsp90M. Sequentially, Hsp90 ATPase activity is triggered by Hsp90 ATPase-1 (Aha1) along with the dissociation of Hsp70 and Hop, which promotes closure of the Hsp90 homodimer.(23) Unfolded substrates are assembled on Hsp90M. Subsequently, the procedure of ATP hydrolysis is catalyzed by PP5 on Hsp90N, leading to substrate folding and opening the N-terminal domain of the Hsp90 dimer to restore the initial conformation, which results in the release of mature client proteins.(24) When Hsp90 is inhibited by modulators, the process of substrates folding is terminated, and these substrates are ubiquitinylated via CHIP for degradation. Hence, the progression of the ATPase cycle, the regulation of co-chaperones, and the biological function of client proteins are essential for studying Hsp90 inhibition strategies and exploring potential clinical applications.

    4. Hsp90 and Disease

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    As a key chaperone, the upregulation of Hsp90 plays an important role in the excessive accumulation of many client proteins, which are critical pathogenic factors in numerous diseases, including cancer, inflammation, neurodegeneration, and viral infection. Increased levels of Hsp90 exist in many aberrant cells. For example, upregulation of Hsp90 is regarded as a vital biomarker in cancer diagnosis. Thus, developing agents to inhibit the Hsp90 chaperone cycle is a valuable strategy to treat such intractable diseases.

    4.1. Hsp90 and Cancer

    The ATPase activity of Hsp90 is a decisive factor in the Hsp90 chaperone cycle. ATP binding can trigger the folding of client proteins assembled on Hsp90. Many client proteins of Hsp90 are oncogenic proteins, including tyrosine kinase receptors (such as EGFR, Her2, and VEGFR), signal transduction proteins (such as Bcr-Abl, Alk, Braf, and Akt), transcription factors (such as androgen receptors and HIF1α), cell cycle regulatory proteins (such as Cdk4, Rb, and cyclin D), antiapoptotic proteins (such as Bcl2 and survivin).(25) The hallmarks of tumor cells can be divided into six categories: (i) overexpression of growth signals; (ii) insensitivity to antiproliferation signals; (iii) evasion of apoptosis; (iv) infinite division of aberrant cells; (v) activation of angiogenesis; and (vi) tissue invasion and metastasis. Oncogenic clients of Hsp90 are involved in these neoplastic hallmarks, leading to addiction to Hsp90 in the development of many cancer cases.(2) For example, Cdk4 is responsible for the G1 to S phase transition of cell cycle, which promotes the proliferation of tumor cells. Hsp90-Cdc37-Cdk4 complex is necessary for the maturation of Cdk4. Hsp90-Cdc37 interaction selectively stabilizes Cdk4 and Cdk6, which are rapidly degraded without binding to Hsp90. Steroid hormone receptors, including estrogen and androgen receptors, are also a class of clients of Hsp90. Overexpression of estrogen receptors is observed in most of breast cancer patients. Similarly, androgen receptors are critical factors in the development of prostate cancer. Both of these steroid receptors are Hsp90-dependent clients and activate their target genes after binding to Hsp90. In addition, angiogenesis is intensively required for the expending tumor volume. Angiogenesis is activated by vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). Receptors of VEGF (VEGFR) are also Hsp90-dependent clients. Inhibition of Hsp90 function reduces the level of VEGFR, resulting in the blocking of the transmission of angiogenesis signals.(26) Some excellent review articles have discussed the impartible relationship between the clients of Hsp90 and the development of cancer.(26,27) In summary, inhibition of the activity of Hsp90 ATPase can induce the degradation of client proteins through the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway. Thus, tumors addicted to these client proteins are sensitive to Hsp90 inhibition. Currently, trials of monotherapy or combined therapy with Hsp90N ATP inhibitors(28) for the treatment of refractory solid tumors and hematological neoplasms have entered into different clinical phases (https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/results?cond=&term=hsp90&cntry=&state=&city=&dist=).

    4.2. Hsp90 and Autoimmune/Inflammatory Diseases

    Autoimmune diseases are a series of immune disorders that are highly correlated with chronic inflammation. To date, specific immunosuppressive agents with hypotoxicity remain to be identified. An obvious symbol of Hsp90 inhibition is activation of the HSF1 pathway, which is a positive factor for cancer cell growth and survival but is an inducer of anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive genes. Based on the effect of Hsp90 on the immune system, its potential application in autoimmune diseases has been increasingly researched.(29) Using a mouse model of encephalomyelitis, Bae et al. revealed that geldanamycin and its analog 17-AAG alleviated the development of encephalomyelitis in mice, which impaired the function of T cells, in turn contributing to the decreased IL-2 expression mediated by 17-AAG.(30) Another Hsp90N inhibitor, SNX-7081, was reported to suppress ankle and knee swelling in a rat model of collagen-induced arthritis and adjuvant-induced arthritis.(31) Furthermore, EC144, a synthetic Hsp90 inhibitor, exerted the equivalent effect on collagen-induced arthritis mice model.(32) Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a typical autoimmune disease with overexpression of Hsp90, which entices researchers to explore the application of Hsp90 inhibition in SLE. 17-DMAG was demonstrated to decrease proteinuria, a universal phenomenon in patients with SLE, and to simulate the production of CD8-positive T cells.(33) Kasperkiewicz et al. revealed that treatment with 17-DMAG was effective in a mouse model of epidermolysis bullosa acquisita, hindering the expression of inflammatory factors, including IFN-γ, TNF-α, and IL-17.(34) In addition, the anti-inflammatory activity of 17-AAG was subsequently verified in rat and mouse models of lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-induced uveitis (EIU) and sepsis.(34) The Grp94 isoform is crucial for intestinal inflammation. Liu et al. reported that Grp94 could play an essential role in maintaining gut homeostasis through direct regulation of the canonical Wnt signaling pathway.(35) Grp94-KO mice and intestinal tissue-specific Grp94-KO mice developed serious intestinal lesions. Recently, our group demonstrated that a novel selective inhibitor of Grp94 had a positive effect in a DSS-induced ulcerative colitis (UC) mouse model.(36) This is the first evidence to confirm the potential therapeutic efficacy of Grp94 inhibitors in UC. In general, these results suggest that blockade of Hsp90 may provide a novel therapeutic method and a potential molecular target for autoimmune diseases.

    4.3. Hsp90 and Neurodegenerative Diseases

    Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is an irreversible neurodegenerative disease in which integrated pathogenesis must be further examined. Excessive accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) in senile plaques and misfolding of the microtubule-associated protein Tau are considered to be two critical stimuli of AD. According to these findings, the relationship between Hsp90 chaperone function and AD pathogenesis has attracted extensive attention.(37) Hsp90 inhibition was reported to alleviate Aβ-induced toxicity and repair Aβ-induced cognitive impairment in mice.(38) Moreover, Hsp90 mediates the maturation of Tau, leading to the accumulation of pathological Tau.(39) In addition, substrates of Hsp90, including GSK3β and Akt, promote phosphorylation of Tau. Luo et al. demonstrated that blockade of Hsp90 inhibited the pathogenic activity of Tau and protected cells from aggregation, leading to tauopathies in cellular and mouse models.(40) Hence, inhibition of Hsp90 appears to reduce the levels of misfolded and hyperphosphorylated Tau protein and to suppress progressive neurodegeneration. The potential application of Hsp90 inhibitors in AD has been explored. 17-AAG reduced brain injury and improved cognitive processes in a mouse model.(38) Novobiocin and its derivatives, which are regarded to be Hsp90 C-terminal inhibitors, were demonstrated to protect cells from Aβ-induced cell death.(40) In addition, withaferin A (WA) interfered with the Hsp90/Cdc37 interaction, inducing instability in leucine-rich repeat kinase 2 (LRRK2), which has been found to be mutated in patients with familial and sporadic Parkinson’s disease and AD.(41)

    4.4. Hsp90 and Viral Infections

    Studies have shown that increased Hsp90 plays crucial roles in the viral life cycle and host stress response. First, exosome-mediated viral transmission is partially regulated by Hsp90. The replication competent complex Ago2-miR122-Hsp90 has been identified in exosomes from hepatitis C virus (HCV)-infected patients, in which Hsp90 stabilizes the RNA-replication complex by binding with Ago2.(42) Treatment with 17-DMAG was reported to markedly suppress exosome-mediated HCV transmission, suggesting the potential of Hsp90 inhibitors in viral diseases.(43) Second, host innate immune responses can be stimulated during viral infection. However, these responses can be neutralized by utilization of host Hsp90, which interacts with IκB kinase to regulate the immune response to DNA virus and retroviral infections through the NF-κB signaling pathway. Additionally, Hsp90 is an indispensable regulator of the proliferation or apoptosis of virus-infected cells. These results show that the maturation and proliferation of viruses are addicted to the functions of Hsp90. Notably, some Hsp90 inhibitors have been investigated in viral diseases. GDA was demonstrated to block the viral life cycle of hepatitis B virus (HBV), HCV, and herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1).(44) In addition, 17-DMAG was shown to suppress the replication of HCV in a humanized mouse model with liver injury.(43,44) A recent study demonstrated that inhibition of Hsp90 by 17-AAG and NVP-AUY922 disrupted the expression of HIV proteins, preventing rebound for 11 weeks in HIV-infected mice.(45) Vashist et al. reported that targeting Hsp90 in vivo could disrupt the replication of norovirus. Thus, Hsp90 can be regarded as a potential target for the treatment of viral infections.(46)

    5. Strategies for Hsp90 Inhibition

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    5.1. Inhibitors of Hsp90 ATPase Activity

    Initial efforts to investigate Hsp90 inhibitors focused on suppression of the ATPase activity of Hsp90 via competitive bound to the ATP pocket in the N-terminus. These inhibitors block ATP hydrolysis of Hsp90 and subsequently impede the closure of the N-terminus of the Hsp90 dimer, which seriously impairs the Hsp90 chaperone cycle in the maturation of client proteins. Studies of the underlying biological mechanisms have allowed the classification of Hsp90 ATPase inhibitors into two types: (i) structures that bind to the Hsp90N ATP pocket and (ii) those that affect Hsp90 C-terminal ATPase activity. In this section, the development of these ATPase inhibitors is described.

    5.1.1. Inhibitors Targeting the Hsp90 N-Terminus

    Hsp90N ATP inhibitors can be divided into four classes according to the main scaffold: ansamycin-based, resorcinol-based, purine-based, and benzamide-based. Geldanamycin (GDA, 1), is the first prominent Hsp90 inhibitor that exhibited potent antitumor activity via targeting the N-terminal ATP binding pocket of Hsp90. Preclinical trials of 1 were terminated due to its hepatotoxicity, in vivo instability, and poor solubility,(47) which prompted research on structural modifications based on the skeleton of ansamycin (Figure 3). Among these analogs, 17-AAG (2, IC50 = 31 nM) was the first Hsp90 inhibitor in clinical studies. Following that study, 17-DMAG (3, IC50 = 24 nM) was identified and shown to maintain biological activity and had improved solubility.(48) Additionally, two additional representative GDA derivatives, IPI-504 (4, EC50 = 64 nM) and IPI-493 (5, EC50 = 34 nM), were subsequently developed.(49) Both of these analogs have undergone clinical trials as an oral formulation with appropriate pharmacokinetics.
    Radicicol (RDC, 6, IC50 = 30 nM) displayed high affinity for Hsp90 in an in vitro ATPase assay, with a Kd value of 19 nM. However, it lacks in vivo activity due to the rapid metabolism of allylic epoxide and α-, β-, γ-, and δ-unsaturated ketones. To improve stability, KF25706 (7, IC50 = 39 nM) was found to exhibit potency comparable to that of radicicol against multiple human neoplastic cell lines. An X-ray crystallographic study of radicicol-Hsp90 revealed that the resorcinol moiety formed a hydrogen bonding network with residues (Asp93 and Thr184) in the ATP pocket, which primarily facilitated the high affinity.(50) Based on the results presented in the crystal structural map, the resorcinol scaffold was maintained as a critical pharmacophore for the identification of several compounds under clinical investigation as anticancer agents via a fragment-based approach and high-throughput screening (Figure 4). Fragment 8 was screened and found to bind to Hsp90N with an affinity of 790 μM.(51) The co-crystal structure presented obvious defects in the interaction model with the ATP pocket, and stretching of fragment 8 resulted in compound 9, which had superior affinity (Kd = 0.54 nM).(51) Despite its potent antiproliferative activity, compound 9 displayed high plasma clearance in a mouse model, prompting optimization concentrated on the pharmacokinetic and physicochemical properties. Ultimately, compound AT-13387 (10, Kd = 0.71 nM) was selected to be advanced into clinical trials due to its high binding affinity for Hsp90 against various human tumor cell lines, as well as low plasma protein-binding activity and appropriate aqueous solubility.(52) Avila et al. reported an efficient assay to evaluate the ATPase activity of Hsp90;(53) compound 11 (IC50 = 280 nM) was identified from a library containing ∼50 000 compounds through high-throughput screening.(54) The weak antiproliferative activity of 11 in HCT116 cells prompted structural modification focused on potency. Compound 12, with a higher antiproliferative activity value of 260 nM, was identified and used as a template for further modification.(55) Accordingly, insight into the crystal structure of Hsp90 binding to 12 promoted the subsequent structure-based modification on the three rings with the aim of forming an appended hydrogen bond and improving solubility. Subsequently, NVP-AUY922 (13, IC50 = 21 nM) was demonstrated to be a novel Hsp90 inhibitor with increased potency and was advanced into clinical trials for a series of cancer indications.(56) In 2014, our group reported a novel series of tetrahydropyrido[4,3-d]pyrimidine compounds with inhibitory activity against Hsp90 through the construction of a rapid overlay of chemical structural (ROCS) model based on the conformation of AT-13387 in the co-crystal.(57) A comprehensive structure–activity relationship (SAR) study was conducted to improve Hsp90 inhibitory activity and drug-like properties. Analog 14 exhibited an inhibitory value of 28 nM against Hsp90 and positive antitumor activity in an HCT116 xenograft model.(58) Additionally, 14 possessed good physicochemical properties and favorable ADME properties, suggesting its potential for further preclinical evaluation. Specifically, compared with NVP-AUY922 and TAS-116, 14 manifested no ocular toxicity in a rat retinal damage model. Liang et al. introduced unnatural amino acids (Tic) into a resorcinol fragment to mimic the isoindoline group of AT-13387 occupying the lipophilic pocket in the ATP binding site. As a result, compound 15 had a different chemical scaffold and was found to target Hsp90 in a cellular thermal shift (CETSA) assay and inhibit MDA-MB-231 cell viability with an IC50 value of 980 nM.(59)
    In addition to ansamycin and resorcinol, Hsp90 inhibitors with purine-based structures were inspired by a focus on the endogenous ligand ATP. Eventually, five purine derivatives (Figure 5) (PU-H71, BIIB021, BIIB028, CUDC-305, and MPC-3100) were identified and advanced to clinical evaluation. PU-H71 (16, IC50 = 90 nM) is an orally available inhibitor.(60) Another clinical purine-based inhibitor is BIIB028 (18), which is a prodrug of BIIB021 (17, IC50 = 310 nM) that increased the therapeutic window for intravenous administration. Additionally, CUDC-305 (19, IC50 = 100 nM) was shown to possess good oral bioavailability and tumor suppression activity.(61) MPC-3100 (20, IC50 = 540 nM) was selected as a clinical candidate with an impressive Hsp90 inhibition profile and superior pharmacokinetics (Figure 5).(62) Fragment 21 was screened by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), and compound 22 was identified from virtual screening (Figure 6). According to the crystal structures of both fragment 21 and compound 22, compound 23 with 2-aminothieno[2,3-d]pyrimidine (Figure 6) was synthesized and found to inhibit the activity of Hsp90 with an IC50 value of 1250 μM via FP assay, and structural modification was performed according to the crystal structure.(63) Among the analogs, NVP-BEP800 (24), with an Hsp90 inhibition value of 58 nM via FP assay, was efficacious in preclinical trials in a BT474 human breast cancer xenograft mouse model (Figure 6).(63)
    Another class of Hsp90N ATPase inhibitors is the benzamide-based class (Figure 7). Two hits with Hsp90 inhibitory activity (25, IC50 = 479 nM; 26, IC50 = 641 nM) were screened and displayed sub-micromolar inhibition rates in a time-resolved fluorescence resonance energy transfer (TR-FRET) assay.(64) Both of these compounds were selected as starting points for structural modification to enhance potency and maintain pharmacokinetic properties, leading to the discovery of XL888 (27, IC50 = 24 nM), which is in the early stages of clinical trials.(65) In addition, Huang et al. performed a focused library screen targeting a series of ATPases. Compound 28 has a benzamide scaffold and exhibited moderate Hsp90 inhibitory activity and superior selectivity for the Hsp90N ATP binding site, with a Kd value of 3.7 μM in an 8-pt non-enzymatic ATPase assay. Computational chemistry and crystal structures guided the structural modification of benzamide derivatives, leading to SNX-2112 (29, IC50 = 3 nM), which possessed a 230-fold higher affinity for Hsp90 than 28.(66) In HT-29 cell lines, SNX-2112 showed excellent antiproliferative activity, and its oral form SNX-5422 (30, IC50 = 32 nM) showed in vivo potency, delaying growth by 67% in an HT-29 mouse model.(67)

    5.1.2. Inhibitors Targeting the Hsp90 C-Terminus

    Another ATP binding pocket is found in the Hsp90 C-terminus. Some natural products and their derivatives (Figure 8 and Figure 9) have been reported to target the Hsp90C-ATP pocket and exhibit antitumor activity.(12) Novobiocin (31) was discovered as the first Hsp90C inhibitor with Hsp90 inhibitory activity and moderate antiproliferative effects on SKBR3 cells.(68) The levels of Hsp90-dependent clients (Raf-1, p185erbB2, mutant p53, and p60v-src) were observably reduced after treatment with novobiocin at 800 μM in SKBR3 cells. In vivo administration of 31 reduced the level of Raf-1 in murine splenocytes without altering the splenic content of gelsolin.(69) To improve the antitumor activity of 31, a comprehensive SAR study was performed. Among the identified analogs, 32 induced the degradation of Hsp90 clients (p-Akt and HIF-1α) via a different mechanism compared with 17-AAG.(70) Western blotting revealed that 32 did not induce the upregulation of Hsp90α/β and Hsp70, but 17-AAG did. Compound 33 exhibited potent antiproliferative activity, with IC50 values of 0.14 and 0.64 μM against SKBR3 and MCF-7 cells, respectively.(71) The Hsp90 clients, including Her2, Raf-1, and Akt, were degraded in a concentration-dependent manner. In 2017, our group investigated the structural modification of novobiocin and identified compound 34 with potent activity against the MCF-7 and SKBR3 cell lines.(72) The levels of Hsp90 clients, including Akt, Erk, and CDK6, were reduced in MCF-7 cells without the upregulation of Hsp90 and Hsp70. In addition, 34 showed inhibitory activity against cell migration in vitro and an antitumor effect in vivo in a 4T1 breast xenograft mouse model. Notably, these analogs of novobiocin inhibited Hsp90 without triggering HSR.(72) Deguelin (35), a naturally occurring rotenoid, was suggested to downregulate clients of Hsp90 (Cdk4, Akt, eNOS, and MEK1/2).(73) Deguelin bound to ATP in an ATP-Sepharose assay without affecting the ATP pocket in Hsp90N.(74) These results indicated that deguelin might bind to the ATP pocket in Hsp90C. Furthermore, 36 and 37, which are derivatives of deguelin, both exhibited potent antiproliferative activity in vitro and showed lower cytotoxicity against normal cells compared to deguelin. Compound 37 exhibited potent antiangiogenic activity in a zebrafish model.(75) Epigallocatechin gallate (ECGC, 38) was shown to exhibit antiproliferative activity against pancreatic cancer cells by reducing the levels of Hsp90 client proteins (Akt, Cdk4, Raf-1, Her-2, and pErk). Proteolytic footprinting and ATP-agarose pulldown assays demonstrated that 38 bound to Hsp90C without affecting the N-terminal ATP pocket.(76) Structural modification of 38 resulted in analog 39, which had improved antitumor activity of greater than 18-fold against MCF-7 cells.(77) Additionally, derrubone (40) and silybin (42) were shown to possess antitumor activity related to targeting Hsp90C. Furthermore, their analogs (41, a derivative of derrubone, and 43, a derivative of silybin) were designed and exhibited improved antiproliferative activity against MCF-7 cells, resulting in the downregulation of Her-2 and Raf.(78,79) Compared with inhibition of Hsp90N, targeting the C-terminal ATP pocket produces a negative effect on client proteins of Hsp90 and stabilizes Hsp70 without initiating the HSR. However, the efficacy of Hsp90C inhibitors against tumor cells and the molecular mechanism of the binding mode are remain unclear. In 2011, the potential binding site in Hsp90C was explored by protease fingerprinting and photoaffinity labeling utilizing LC-MS/MS.(80) The binding mode of Hsp90 and novobiocin was generated by a homology model of hHsp90α. Novobiocin binds to a pocket in the open conformation of the Hsp90C comprising the sequence of Glu537 to ASN686. Marcu and co-workers proposed that novobiocin bound to the Hsp90 C terminal site consisting of residues 538–728 through truncation studies.(68) In addition, it was reported that novobiocin might bind to Hsp90 after the dimerization of its C terminus prevented ATP binding to the Hsp90 N terminal pocket (Figure 10).(80,81) Mutational analysis showed that critical residues in the Hsp90N ATP binding pocket did not affect binding of novobiocin. In summary, inhibitors targeting Hsp90C ATPase activity are promising because most of them do not induce HSR. However, the structural information of the ATP pocket in Hsp90C and the binding mode with inhibitors remain obscure. Therefore, structural biological analysis of Hsp90C is needed, which is important for designing potent Hsp90 inhibitors without inducing HSR.

    5.2. Inhibitors Directly Disrupting Hsp90 and Its Co-chaperones

    Considering that the different functions of the Hsp90 chaperone machinery are dependent on the associated co-chaperones, selective Hsp90 inhibition with reduced toxicity and elevated selectivity may be achieved by disrupting certain protein–protein interactions (PPIs). N-terminal inhibitors will impair Hsp90 before the chaperone machinery is initiated. In contrast, inhibitors targeting Hsp90 and its co-chaperone interactions act via an entirely different mechanism and may provide an alternative pathway to avoid the toxicity induced by Hsp90 pan-inhibition. Targeting the interactions between Hsp90 and its co-chaperones may suppress the maturation of partial Hsp90 substrates without impacting the whole client protein (Figure 11). Consequently, disrupting the interaction between Hsp90 and its co-chaperones has emerged as a different strategy for Hsp90 inhibition and has received the considerable attention of medicinal chemists, with some achievements being made in this area.

    5.2.1. Targeting the Hsp90-Cdc37 Protein–Protein Interaction

    Human Cdc37 (50 kDa) consists of 378 amino residues and has been divided into three domains. The highly conserved N-terminus of Cdc37 (Cdc37N) is responsible for binding to kinases, and the middle domain and C-terminus are involved in the interaction with Hsp90. Oncogenic kinases, such as Akt, Cdk4, Erk, and B-Raf, depend on Cdc37 and the subsequent assembly of the Hsp90-Cdc37-kinase ternary complex.(82,83) Increased Cdc37 is observed in various cancers, such as prostate carcinoma, anaplastic large-cell lymphoma, acute myelocytic leukemia, HCC, and multiple myeloma.(82) In addition, knockdown of Cdc37 induced growth arrest in prostate cancer cells.(84) Cdc37 can specifically recognize at least 90% of the unfolded kinase-ome before interacting with Hsp90.(85) The entire Cdc37-dependent kinase-ome has been summarized by the laboratory of Didier Picard on their Web site (https://www.picard.ch/downloads/Cdc37interactors.pdf). These kinases comprise a complex network of signaling cascades that regulate neoplastic cell cycle and proliferation.(86) Compared with the inferior specificity of Hsp90 for client proteins in cell lines, the oncogenic kinase-ome strongly depends on Cdc37 in tumors. Polier et al. found that ATP-competitive inhibitors, such as vemurafenib and lapatinib, impeded the interaction of Cdc37 with oncogenic kinases such as B-Raf and Her2 in cellular assays, blocking these kinases from accessing Hsp90-Cdc37 and leading to subsequent degradation.(87) These results suggested that part of the efficacy of ATP-competitive kinase inhibitors is attributed to inhibition of the formation of the Hsp90-Cdc37-kinase complex. The crystal structure of yeast Hsp90-Cdc37 (PDB: 1US7) was first determined by Roe and co-workers,(85) and indicated that the M domain of Cdc37 binds to Hsp90N and partially overlaps the N-terminal nucleotide binding pocket (Figure 12). The Hsp90-Cdc37 interaction pocket neighbors the ATP binding pocket in Hsp90N, with Arg167 on Cdc37 shallowly inserting into the mouth of the ATP pocket. Heteronuclear NMR spectroscopy was conducted to map the Hsp90-Cdc37 complex from human (PDB: 2K5B), and the conclusion was drawn that Leu205 of Cdc37 is a critical residue in the binding to Hsp90.(88)
    The affinity of the Hsp90-Cdc37 interaction was determined in vitro by ITC at the low micromole level (Kd = 1.46 μM). In 2017, the crystal structure of Hsp90-Cdc37-Cdk4 (PDB: 5FWL), reported by Agard, provided significant evidence for the chaperone-kinase interaction.(89) In addition, the crystal structure suggests that the Hsp90-Cdc37-kinase interaction is highly dynamic (Figure 12). The binding site of Cdc37 was transferred from Hsp90N to Hsp90M, indicating that the Hsp90-Cdc37 PPI is highly flexible and that Hsp90 contains two binding sites for the Cdc37 interaction. Currently, most of the reported regulators of the Hsp90-Cdc37 PPI are natural products (Figure 13). In 2008, Zhang et al. reported that celastrol (44, IC50 = 3 μM) exhibited antitumor activity against the Panc-1 cell line and disrupted the Hsp90-Cdc37 interaction at a concentration of 10 μM in an immunoprecipitation assay.(90) In addition, an ATP-Sepharose pulldown assay provided evidence that 44 did not impact ATP binding at a concentration of 1 μM, suggesting a different mechanism of Hsp90 inhibition compared to that of traditional Hsp90 inhibitors. 44 markedly decreased the levels of client proteins, including Cdk4 and Akt. In a mouse model of pancreatic cancer, 44 exhibited excellent inhibitory activity against tumor growth (80%). Using proteolytic fingerprinting assay, Zhang et al. demonstrated that 44 modified Hsp90C to achieve allosteric regulation and disrupted the Hsp90-Cdc37 complex.(91) A GST pulldown assay indicated that the quinone methide structure of 44 is an important pharmacophore, as dihydrocelastrol diacetate led to a 2-fold decrease in the inhibitory effect on the Hsp90-Cdc37 PPI. However, Sreeramulu et al. proposed another mechanism in which 44 covalently bound to cysteine residues in Cdc37N via the Michael reaction.(92) This binding mode was determined by an 1H–15N heteronuclear single-quantum correlation (HSQC) experiment in which most of the cross peaks disappeared after the addition of 44 to 15N-labeled Cdc37. Based on these results, our group attempted to modify the C-29 carboxyl moiety of 44 to investigate the SAR and to improve the drug-like properties. Among the 23 derivatives, 45 exhibited a 2-fold increase in the antiproliferative activity against the MCF-7, Panc-1, and A549 cell lines and possessed superior permeability compared with 44.(93) Treatment with 10 μM withaferin A (WA, 46) dissociated the Hsp90-Cdc37 complex in a coimmunoprecipitation (CO-IP) assay in Panc-1 cells. Furthermore, the levels of client proteins dependent on the Hsp90-Cdc37 interaction, including Akt and Cdk4, were reduced in a Western blotting assay.(94) In addition, 46 displayed antiproliferative activity against a series of pancreatic cancer cell lines (IC50 = 1.24 μM, Panc-1; IC50 = 2.93 μM, MiaPaCa2; and IC50 = 2.78 μM, BxPc3) without an effect on the ATPase activity of Hsp90. Using a WA-biotin pulldown assay, Yu et al. illustrated that 46 covalently binds to the cysteine-containing C-terminus of human Hsp90 but not the N-terminus.(94) These results suggested that 46 is an indirect inhibitor of the Hsp90-Cdc37 PPI via allosteric modulation of Hsp90C and is dependent on cysteine residues. Another Hsp90-Cdc37 PPI inhibitor is sulforaphane (47), which was proven to bind to Hsp90C via an immunoprecipitation assay. In addition, 47 was reported to impair Hsp90 chaperones via another mechanism that promoted hyperacetylation of Hsp90.(95) Another covalent inhibitor is kongensin A (48), which disrupts the Hsp90-Cdc37 PPI and thus blocks RIP3-dependent necroptosis in HT-29 cells by covalently binding Cys420 on Hsp90M.(96) Mutations of all cysteines (Cys366, Cys420, Cys521, Cys564, Cys589, and Cys590) in Hsp90 revealed that 48 specifically binds to Cys420 via a covalent mechanism; the selectivity was proven by mass spectrometry. Huang et al. used chemoproteomics to identify FW-04-804 (49) targeting Hsp90N in the Hsp90-Cdc37 binding pocket and inhibited the Hsp90-Cdc37 interaction by an immunoprecipitation assay in SKBR3 cell lysates with limited interference with ATPase activity.(97) Interestingly, this compound was more effective in a Her2-overexpressing SKBR3 tumor xenograft model than in a Her2-underexpressing MCF-7 model. In 2017, Li et al. showed that platycodin D (50) disrupted the Hsp90-Cdc37 complex in an immunoprecipitation assay of A549 cell lines without inhibiting the ATPase activity. Specifically, a Western blotting assay showed no change in the Hsp70 level and a reduction in the levels of EGFR, IGF1R, and Cdk6.(98)
    Based on the crystal structure of the Hsp90-Cdc37 complex (PDB: 2K5B), our group focused on the de novo design of regulators targeting the Hsp90-Cdc37 PPI. In a previous work, an active peptide (Pep-1, Ac-KHFGMLRRWDD-NH2) component of 11 residues derived from Cdc37 was reported. Pep-1 was identified by molecular dynamics simulation and molecular mechanics Poisson–Boltzmann surface area (MM-PBSA) analysis combined with in vitro verification. In a competitive biolayer interferometry (BLI) assay, Pep-1 disrupted the Hsp90-Cdc37 interaction in a concentration-dependent manner and showed affinity for Hsp90N by ITC, with a Kd value of 6.90 μM.(99)Pep-1 possessed weak ATPase inhibitory activity at 3 μM. This peptide is a non-natural product inhibitor of the Hsp90-Cdc37 PPI and is a breakthrough. Next, to improve the physicochemical properties and binding affinity, a SAR study of Pep-1 was conducted by mutation and shrinkage of residues, leading to the identification of an abbreviated Pep-5 (Ac-HFGMLRR-NH2, Kd = 5.99 μM).(100) Our group studied the interaction hotspot between Hsp90 and Cdc37, resulting in the discovery of a heptapeptide that suppressed the activity of Hsp90-Cdc37 at low micromolar levels. Based on these results, a pharmacophore model was generated according to the critical interactions of Hsp90-Pep1 (Figure 14A), and a structure-based virtual screening workflow was conducted to identify a small molecule that disrupts the Hsp90-Cdc37 PPI. Subsequently, 51 was identified and showed moderate inhibition (100 μM, 59.33%) of Hsp90-Cdc37 binding in a homogeneous time-resolved fluorescence (HTRF) assay and weak ATPase inhibitory activity (100 μM, < 10%) in a GDA-FP assay.(101) A SAR study of compound 52 (Figure 14B) showed a maintained inhibition rate (100 μM, 79.4%) of Hsp90-Cdc37 in an HTRF assay and antiproliferative activity with an IC50 of 14.67 μM, representing a 4-fold increase compared to that obtained with 51 in SKBR3 cells. Western blotting proved that compound 52 induced the degradation of Hsp90 clients in a concentration-dependent manner in SKBR3 cells, including Akt and Cdk4, and disrupted the Hsp90-Cdc37 PPI in a GST pulldown assay. The binding mode of compound 52 provides evidence that the identified interaction hotspot is an effective binding site for the Hsp90-Cdc37 PPI. According to molecular dynamics calculation and ITC determinations of mutant affinities, we confirmed the critical residues including R167 on Cdc37 and E47 and Q133 on Hsp90, which is one of the binding determinants in the interaction of Hsp90-Cdc37. Based on these results, we designed a hierarchical strategy that combines cascade docking, experimental assays, and chemical optimization, and an inhibitor termed DDO-5936 (53) was developed (Figure 14C), which potently disrupted Hsp90-Cdc37 both in vitro and in vivo.(102) To identify the potential binding site between Hsp90 and 53, we obtained a 1H–15N transverse relaxation optimized spectroscopy (TROSY) heteronuclear single-quantum coherence (HSQC) spectrum, and the critical residues (E47 and Q133) of Hsp90 showed gradual shifts in NMR resonance positions upon titration with 53 in a dose-dependent manner. Compound 53 selectively downregulated Cdc37-dependent kinases including Cdk4/6 and p-Akt in HCT-116 cells, leading to cell cycle arrest and antiproliferative activity. Compound 53 showed efficiency in HCT116 tumor cell xenografts with a good safety profile in multiple organs including the lung, liver, and spleen.(102) Compound 53 could be regarded as the first small-molecule inhibitor targeting Hsp90-Cdc37 PPI with a clear binding mode and on-target specificity. Recently, Xu et al. found that KBU2046 (54) disrupted the Hsp90-Cdc37 PPI without cytotoxicity and selectively inhibited cell motility and invasion in tumor cell lines (Figure 14C).(103) Interestingly, 54 individually binds to neither Hsp90 nor Cdc37 according to isothermal titration calorimetry, fluorescence-based thermal shift assays, and BLI assays, but it binds exclusively to the Hsp90-Cdc37 heterocomplex. In prostate and breast cancer mouse models, 54 markedly inhibited metastasis and prolonged survival. In addition, Chen et al. reported an inhibitor with a triazine scaffold, DCZ3112 (55), that targeted Hsp90N and suppressed the Hsp90-Cdc37 PPI (Figure 14C).(104) Compound 55 potently inhibited the viability of Her-2-positive breast cancer cell lines, including SKBR3 and BT-474, cells that are resistant to the Hsp90 ATPase inhibitor GDA. Moreover, 55 produced G1-phase arrest, downregulated the phosphorylation of Akt and Erk, and maintained antitumor activity in Her2-positive BT-474 xenografts.

    5.2.2. Targeting the Hop-Hsp90 Protein–Protein Interaction

    Sti1/HOP plays a key role in facilitating unfolded client transferred from Hsp70 to Hsp90 for maturation. The Hsp90-Hop-Hsp70 ternary complex depends on two TPR domains on Hop: TPR1 and TPR2A.(10) Although the binding affinity of TPR2A for Hsp90 is moderate, with a Kd value of 11 μM,(10) this interaction is absolutely critical to initiate the Hsp90 chaperone cycle (Figure 16A). Thus, the hypothesis of Hsp90-Hop PPI inhibition emerged as a potential alternative approach to inhibit Hsp90 activity (Figure 15). Surprisingly, Regan and co-workers demonstrated the feasibility of this strategy with a designed TPR domain that could competitively bind to Hsp90C and disrupt the Hsp90-Hop-Hsp70 complex. Six active compounds (56–61) with a pyrimido[5,4-e][1,2,4]triazine-5,7-dione structural core were identified from the NCGC compound library via an AlphaScreen assay (see Figure 18). The isothermal titration calorimetry results showed that compound 56 bound to TPR2A at a 1:1 ratio with a Kd value of 16 μM.(105) Importantly, these compounds did not induce elevated Hsp70 expression, which is an undesired trait of Hsp90N inhibitors. Hsp70 induces HSR and inhibits apoptosis, which may contribute to drug resistance and toxicity. Thus, these compounds disrupted Hsp90-TPR2A (Kd < 1 μM in a competitive FP assay) in vitro and decreased the overexpression of the Hsp90-dependent client Her2 without Hsp70 upregulation in BT474 and SKBR3 cells. These compounds may represent a novel class of Hsp90 inhibitors with a distinct mechanism and superior safety profile. In subsequent studies, the TNBC cell line MDA-MB-231 was proven to be sensitive to compound 57 (IC50 = 1.75 μM) due to disruption of the Hsp90-Hop PPI and a reduction in the Hsp70 level.(105) Moreover, 57 negatively affected the level of Cdc37, which may explain the decreased levels of Hsp90-dependent kinases, such as JNK1/2 and p38. Recently, Wang et al. reported 62 as a Hsp90 inhibitor with pyrimidine that acted by disrupting the Hsp90-Hop interaction(106) (Figure 18).Compound 62 decreased the levels of Hsp90 client proteins, including Bcr-Abl, Raf-1, Akt, and Cdk6, but induced Hsp70 expression in SKBR3, A431, MCF-7, and SNU-5 cells. Disruption of the Hsp90-Hop interaction by 62 is reduced by thiol oxidation rather than by competitive binding to the Hsp90-Hop interaction pocket, triggering G0/G1 cell cycle arrest and apoptosis. An α,β-unsaturated bond with thiol-reactive scaffold provides the possibility of modifying cysteine residues on Hsp90 and further inhibiting its function. A Western blot with K562 cells showed that Hsp90 client proteins (Bcr-Abl, Raf-1, Akt, Cdk4, and Cdk6) were degraded and that Hsp70 induction was restored upon incubation with the thiol-containing antioxidant dithiothreitol (DTT) before treatment with 62.(106) These results suggested that 62 disrupted the Hsp90-Hop interaction via thiol oxidation. Additionally, 62 showed potential for the treatment of imatinib-resistant leukemia due to its efficacy in a Bcl-Abl point mutation model both in vitro and in vivo.

    5.2.3. Other Disruptors of Hsp90 and Its Co-chaperones

    Co-chaperones with a TPR domain can identify the MEEVD sequence in Hsp90C.(107) In addition to the aforementioned Hop, there are four other immunophilins that are TPR-dependent co-chaperones of Hsp90: FK506 binding protein 52 (FKBP52), FKBP51, cyclophilin 40 (Cyp40), and FKBP38 (Figure 16B). Immunophilins selectively control the maturation of hormone receptors during Hsp90 chaperone machinery assembly, which can promote cell growth via a signaling cascade. Since complexes of Hsp90 and immunophilins regulate cell growth, blocking this interaction in tumor cells may induce cellular apoptosis, leading to a unique chemotherapy for cancer. In 2014, McAlpine and co-workers identified the first small molecule (63) that could disrupt the association between Hsp90 and immunophilins (Figure 18). In HeLa cells, this compound significantly decreased the level of immunophilins and moderately reduced the levels of the corresponding client protein, glucocorticoid receptor (GR). Notably, treatment with 63 did not affect the Hsp70 levels in HeLa cells, indicating that this compound did not trigger the HSR.(108)
    Aha1 is involved in the Hsp90 chaperone cycle by accelerating the N-terminal association of Hsp90 dimers (Figure 17).(109)Two binding modes of Hsp90 and Aha1 have been reported: one is the interaction of Hsp90M-Aha1N, and the other is the dynamic interaction between Hsp90N-Aha1C.(109) Additionally, this interaction is critical in the quality control of mutants of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), which is implicated in the development of cystic fibrosis.(110) Thus, the Hsp90-Aha1 interaction is believed to be involved in the selective binding of client proteins.(111) However, the regulators of the Hsp90-Aha1 PPI require further research. Recently, a compound inhibiting the Hsp90-Aha1 complex was identified by Stiegler and colleagues through Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET). Compound 64 (Figure 18) attenuated the Aha1-mediated ATPase activity of Hsp90 but was inefficient in the absence of Aha1.(112) NMR was performed to demonstrate that the binding site of 64 was located in the 15N-labeled Hsp90N rather than in Hsp90M, suggesting that 64 suppressed ATPase activity by partially disrupting the Hsp90-Aha1 interaction at the N-terminal binding site but did not affect the M-terminal binding site in Hsp90. In an in vitro yeast culture assay, 64 markedly inhibited the level of the mineralocorticoid receptor in a concentration-dependent manner, which is a client of Hsp90 associated with the Aha1 interaction. Moreover, 64 stabilized the level of a mutant of CFTR (with the deletion of F508 in the CFTR sequence), whose degradation plays a key role in cystic fibrosis.(112)
    The Hsp90 chaperone cycle is driven not only by ATPase activation but also by the interaction with co-chaperones. Different co-chaperones with specific functions bind to Hsp90 in different stages in the chaperone cycle. For example, Cdc37 loads onto Hsp90 during the early stages of the cycle, introducing unfolded kinases to Hsp90 and inhibiting ATP binding by maintaining Hsp90N cleavage. In contrast, Aha1 accelerates the closed conformation of Hsp90N. Hence, these characteristics of the Hsp90-co-chaperone interaction provide a platform for different inhibition modes of the Hsp90 chaperone cycle. Progress in the field of Hsp90 PPI regulators suggests the feasibility of special inhibition of the Hsp90 chaperone cycle. Although some problems exist with these PPI inhibitors, such as low affinity and elusive mechanisms, some regulators exhibit positive effects on refractory cancer cells, such as TNBC and NSCLC cells. These results provide insights into the network of signaling pathways involved in Hsp90 functions and the application of these pathways to tumor treatment.

    5.3. Selective Inhibition of Hsp90α/β, Grp94, and Trap1

    The Hsp90 chaperone has four isoforms: Hsp90α, Hsp90β, Grp94, and Trap1. To date, the mechanisms of action for Hsp90α and Hsp90β are well known, but Trap1 and Grp94 are less understood. Grp94 is reported to be implicated in innate immunity.(113) Despite the high conservation of the isoforms in the structure map, selective inhibitors of Hsp90 isoforms have attracted much attention from medicinal chemists.(114) Furthermore, selective inhibitors are worthy of further investigation as this would provide deep insight about the biofunction of the individual isoforms. In this section, subtle differences in the structure of the isoforms as well as the selective inhibitors are summarized.

    5.3.1. Selective inhibition of Hsp90α/β

    Hsp90α/β are critical to reduce the levels of mutant huntingtin protein (mHtt), which constantly accumulates in the brain as Huntington’s disease (HD) progresses.(115) Based on the function of Hsp90α/β, the possibility of selectively targeting these cytosolic isoforms of Hsp90 has emerged. In 2013, Ernst and co-workers analyzed the relationship between chemotypes of clinical Hsp90 inhibitors and isoform selectivity.(116) The high degree of conservation in the binding sites of the four isoforms precludes designing isoform-specific inhibitors according to discrepancies between amino acid residues. Surprisingly, the X-ray crystal structure indicates that the conformation of residues 104–111 in the N-terminal ATP binding site is different in Hsp90α/β depending on chemical diversities in the bound ligand (Figure 19A). Purine-based inhibitors, such as compound 17 (BIIB021), possess moderate selectivity due to the induction of an extended α-helix conformation in residues 104–111 in the Hsp90α/β binding site, which forms an incompact hinge in the co-crystal structure of other chemical skeletons, while the binding sites of Trap1 and Grp94 do not have this unique conformation of residues 104–111. These results provide a template for the structure-based design of Hsp90α/β-specific inhibitors (Figure 20) with low toxicity profiles to treat chronic neurodegenerative diseases.
    Based on the binding mode of the moderately selective Hsp90α/β inhibitor SNX-0723 (65, Hsp90α, Ki = 3 nM; Hsp90β, Ki = 4 nM; Grp94, Ki = 375 nM; Trap1, Ki = 1195 nM), a novel compound (66) bearing a benzolactam scaffold was designed by Ernst and co-workers.(117) The level of selectivity to Hsp90α/β was more than 2000-fold increased (Hsp90α, Ki = 5 nM; Hsp90β, Ki = 5 nM; Grp94, Ki > 10 μM; Trap1, Ki > 10 μM), and the physicochemical properties were improved, with oral availability. Compound 66 was shown to facilitate mHtt degradation in vitro and exert consistent effects in HEK cells (mHt, IC50 = 24 nM) with a low toxicity profile. Furthermore, the levels of brain Htt were reduced in rats treated with compound 66; thus, this compound is a potential chemotherapy for HD. An initial investigation of a series of 4-(1H-indol-1-yl)benzamide derivatives was conducted by Ohkubo and colleagues, resulting in the identification of TAS-116 (67) as a potent and orally available inhibitor of Hsp90α/β (Hsp90α, Ki = 34.7 nM; Hsp90β, Ki = 21.3 nM; Grp94 and Trap1, Ki > 50 μM).(118) Notably, 67 exhibited antitumor activity but did not impair the retina in rats, unlike clinical pan-inhibitors in a rat model of NSCLC. However, the selectivity between Hsp90α and Hsp90β was unsolved based on the conformational change in the binding site, due to the high identity (95%) of Hsp90α and Hsp90β. Recently, a Hsp90β-selective inhibitor, 68 (Hsp90α, Kd = 9.55 μM; Hsp90β, Kd = 0.18 μM; Grp94, Kd = 8.48 μM), was identified via the difference in steric hindrance in the Hsp90α/β binding sites.(119) Sequence alignment of Hsp90α/β revealed the subtly distinct composition of residues in the N-terminal ATP pockets: Ala52 and Leu91 in Hsp90β were replaced by Ser52 and Ile91 in Hsp90α.(119) In the co-crystal structures of radicicol and Hsp90α/β, the subpocket in Hsp90β consisting of Ala52 and Leu91 tolerates the bulkier substituents at the 3-position of resorcinol, while the same site in Hsp90α exhibits an unfavorable steric effect. Hence, modification at the 3-position of resorcinol was performed, leading to a highly selective inhibitor of Hsp90β (68) bearing a benzoisoxazole scaffold. A Western blot assay with KUNB31 cells showed that 68 reduced the levels of Hsp90β-dependent client proteins (such as Cdk4/6, Akt, and CXCR4), while Hsp90α-dependent clients (Raf-1, ERK-5, and survivin) were unaffected.(119)

    5.3.2. Selective Inhibition of Grp94

    Many client proteins, such as TLRs, integrins, insulin-like growth factors (IGFs), and immunoglobulins,(120) specifically depend on Grp94.(18) These Grp94-dependent substrates are responsible for cell adhesion, communication, and motility, which are critical processes in tumor metastasis and immunoevasion. In particular, several Grp94-dependent clients play a key role in inflammatory diseases. Therefore, the development of Grp94-selective inhibitors is an attractive means to provide a therapy for cancer and inflammation. Currently, Grp94-selective inhibitors can be divided into three classes: purine-based, benzamide-based, and resorcinol-based (Figure 20). The first class of Grp94-selective inhibitors, which feature a purine scaffold, was identified based on the co-crystal structure of PU-H54 in complex with Grp94 and was reported by Patel et al.(121) This crystal structure contains a ligand-induced hydrophobic site 2 in Grp94 that is blocked in Hsp90α/β and Trap1(Figure 19C).(122) Consequently, Grp94 selectivity was achieved by designing purine-based analogs with a hydrophobic substitution available in the specific site 2 in Grp94.(123) Among this series of compounds, 69 exhibited a more than 100-fold increase in Grp94 selectivity, with an IC50 value of 0.22 μM.(123) In cell-based assays, the levels of several proteins downstream of Grp94 (such as TLR and IGF-II) were measured to provide evidence for the cellular selectivity of 69. TRL9 expression decreased upon inhibition of Grp94 chaperone activity by 69, which in turn suppressed TLR9-mediated TNF-α production. Specifically, accelerated localization in tumors was observed in a tumor-bearing mouse model upon treatment with 69, providing potential opportunities to enhance the therapeutic index and alleviate side effects. This phenomenon should be further studied. On the basis of the unique hydrophobic cleavage in the Grp94 binding pocket, the tetrahydroindazolone moiety of SNX-2112 (29; Hsp90α, Kd = 4 nM; Grp94, Kd = 484 nM) was found to contribute to steric hindrance with site 2 in Grp94, leading to preference for binding with Hsp90α/β.(124) Hence, this fragment was substituted with a pyrrole attached to a phenyl in the 2-position, leading to compound 70, which exhibits more favorable binding to site 2 in Grp94.(124) Compound 70 (Hsp90α, Kd > 100 μM; Grp94, Kd ∼ 440 nM) contains a benzamide scaffold and inhibited the migration of PC-3-MM-2 and MDA-MB-231 cell lines at a concentration of 10 μM. The levels of Grp94-specific clients, including integrin α2, integrin αL, Syne2, VAMP2, and Rab10, were markedly reduced in a Western blot assay with PC3-MM2 cells after treatment with 70. Additionally, compound 70 remarkably induced a decrease in mutant I447N myocilin at 30 μM, which plays a key role in the development of glaucoma. Treatment with 70 at 30 μM did not influence the level of Hsp70 and Akt. These results indicated the potential of 70 for the treatment of metastatic cancer or glaucoma. To identify novel Grp94 inhibitors, our group performed an intensive study of the unique site 2 in Grp94. Analysis of the co-crystal structure of PU-H54 in complex with Hsp90α or Grp94 provided some hints. In the binding pocket of Hsp90α, residue Phe138 is parallel. However, the 8-aryl group of PU-H54 inserts into the induced site 2 in Grp94, and residue Phe199 is oblique (Figure 19C). This “Phe199 shift” in the conformation of Grp94 occurs in the presence of a ligand. Consequently, we hypothesized that the Phe199 shift is the structural basis for Grp94 selectivity and that compounds with rigid groups may exhibit improved Grp94 selectivity by induction of this conformational change. According to these results, our group combined an aryl group with a benzamide scaffold, leading to a novel series of Grp94-selective inhibitors.(36) A comprehensive SAR study was conducted, resulting in analog 71. This analog exhibited notably improved selectivity to Grp94, with an IC50 value of 2 nM, and exhibited no Hsp90α inhibition at 100 μM in FP assay. Treatment of the Panc-1 cell line with 71 reduced the levels of Grp94-dependent clients, including integrin α2 and integrin αL, without influencing Hsp70 and Akt levels. Analog 71 exhibited potent anti-inflammatory activity in a mouse model of dextran sulfate sodium (DSS)-induced UC. In summary, our group provided evidence that the Phe199 shift and rigid moieties in ligands are important structural bases for the design of Grp94-selective inhibitors.(36) Moreover, this conclusion was corroborated by Gewirth et al. via a co-crystal approach.(123) Molecules with resorcinol scaffolds are another typical class of Hsp90 inhibitors. The co-crystal structure of radicicol with Hsp90 or Grp94 revealed a minor difference between the N-terminal ATP binding sites. The resorcinol ring adopted a similar binding mode in Hsp90 and Grp94, while the quinone moiety pointed to a specific site 3 in Grp94 consisting of Phe199, Tyr200, and Trp223 (Figure 19B). Duerfeldt and colleagues exploited the hydrophobic surrogate of the quinone moiety combined with bioisosteres to accommodate the unique subpocket in the binding site of Grp94, contributing to a potent Grp94-selective inhibitor (72) that competitively bound to Grp94 with an IC50 value of 1.15 μM in an FP competition assay.(123) Furthermore, compound 72 affected Grp94-dependent substrates by preventing the transfer of TLRs in HEK293 cells and inhibiting the secretion of IGF-II in C2C12 cells with little effect on cell viability. In contrast, client proteins of Hsp90α/β were not suppressed by compound 72. The inhibitory activity on the growth of Drosophila larvae indicated that it may be a useful Grp94 inhibitor in vivo.(125) To form additional interactions with the unique hydrophobic cleavage site in Grp94 and to thus increase the affinity and selectivity, extensive SAR of the aryl side chain was performed. SAR led to derivative 73 (Kd = 820 nM), which showed good affinity and selectivity for Grp94.(126) Integrins are Grp94-dependent clients responsible for cell adhesion and migration. Therefore, inhibition of Grp94 suppresses integrin maturation, resulting in reduced migration. As expected, 73 exhibited superior antimigratory activity (50% closure at 1 μM) compared to that of 72 (73% closure at 10 μM) in a wound healing scratch assay with MDA-MB-231 cells. According to a Western blot assay, 73 was shown to induce a decrease in integrin α2 expression without affecting Akt expression in a manner dependent on cytosolic isoforms of Hsp90. An in vitro assay on RPMI 8226 cells exhibited a moderate antiproliferative activity with an IC50 value of 9.12 μM. Moreover, no increase in Hsp70 expression was observed, in contrast to the effect of pan-Hsp90 inhibitors.(126)

    5.3.3. Selective Inhibition of Trap1

    Compared to Hsp90α/β and Grp94, scant information about the specific clients and crystal structure of mitochondrial Trap1 has been reported, which has hindered the development and application of Trap-1 selective inhibitors. In 2015, the crystal structure of human Trap1 in complex with PU-H71 (16) was initially determined by Jeong and co-workers for the first time.(127) On the basis of the Trap1-PU-H71 co-crystal structure, the elaborate interaction mechanism was analyzed by researchers. The highly conserved sequence and the extremely subtle distinction of residues in the Trap1 binding site impeded the rational structure-based design of Trap1-selective inhibitors. However, the subcellular localization of Trap1 provided an opportunity to design a conjugate (74, SMTIN-P01) by combining PU-H71 (16) with a mitochondria-targeting triphenylphosphonium (TPP) moiety (Figure 20); this conjugate accumulated in mitochondria to selectively impair the chaperone activity of Trap1.(128) Recently, Park and co-workers reported the design of Trap1 inhibitors without mitochondrial delivery vehicles. The co-crystal structures of PU-H71 (16) in complex with Hsp90 and Trap1 provided insight into the differences in the binding sites in Hsp90 and Trap1. The sequence of Leu172-Phe201 is disordered in the Trap1 binding site compared with that in Hsp90 (Figure 19D), and two conserved residues (Asn171 and Gly202) have different configurations.(129) A structure-based design was developed based on different configurations of the Trap1 active site, leading to the Trap1-selective inhibitor 75 (Trap1, IC50 = 79 nM; Hsp90, IC50 = 698 nM).(129) Compound 75 (Figure 20) induced the loss of mitochondrial membrane potential and the overproduction of mitochondrial ROS, which is involved in Trap1 inhibition, in HeLa cells within 6 h. Furthermore, compound 75 reduced the levels of Hsp90 clients at a concentration of 20 μM, without inducing Hsp70.(129)
    Targeting Hsp90 isoforms has emerged as an alternative strategy to reduce the adverse effects of pan-Hsp90 inhibitors. On the one hand, many co-crystal structures of Hsp90 and their inhibitors have been determined, and these results provide powerful guidance for the structure-based design of selective Hsp90 inhibitors. In addition, the discovery of Hsp90 isoform-selective inhibitors is beneficial for investigating the functions of the unique isoforms. On the other hand, all of the inhibitors occupy the same pocket, and despite the different conformations or residue configurations, these selective inhibitors inhibit the same process in the Hsp90 chaperone cycle by inhibiting ATPase activity. Hence, these selective inhibitors may cause adverse events via inherent defects in their mechanisms of action.

    5.4. Inhibition of Hsp90 Post-translational Modifications

    In addition to co-chaperones, different posttranslational modifications on various residues, including phosphorylation, acetylation, S-nitrosylation, oxidation, and ubiquitination, regulate the chaperone function of Hsp90. Hence, these posttranslational modifications may provide a platform to develop an alternate strategy for the inhibition of Hsp90. Phosphorylation plays a vital role in the posttranslational modification of Hsp90, whose phosphorylation level depends on the cellular environment. Various kinases are involved in Hsp90 phosphorylation and influence Hsp90 chaperone function (Table 2). For instance, the phosphorylation of two threonine residues, which exist only in the N-terminal domain of human Hsp90α, is mediated by DNA-activated protein kinase (DNA-PK).(130) This process is correlated with cellular DNA damage, but the mechanism and phenotypic effects are unknown. Protein kinase A (PKA) was found to phosphorylate Hsp90α on Thr90, which could stimulate the secretion of Hsp90α and thus tumor metastasis. CK2, a ubiquitous serine-threonine acidophilic kinase, phosphorylates Ser226 and Ser255 on Hsp90β, but phosphorylation was not observed in leukemic cells.(131) Moreover, inhibition of the phosphorylation of these two serine residues was reported to play a vital role in the interaction of Hsp90β with the apoptosome, which regulates apoptosis in leukemia.(132) Client proteins also regulate Hsp90 phosphorylation. Maturation of these kinases is mediated by the Hsp90 chaperone cycle and, in turn, can modulate Hsp90 chaperone function via phosphorylation. For example, B-Raf phosphorylates Ser263 on Hsp90α in melanoma cells.(133) Three isoforms of Hsp90, including Hsp90α/β and Grp94, can be phosphorylated by Akt in melanoma cells and are involved in processes underlying glomerular injury.(134) Kinase c-Src was reported to phosphorylate Tyr30 of Hsp90β, which is involved in vascular endothelial growth factor receptor-2 (VEGFR-2) activation.(135) In addition, Tyr24/Tyr38 on Hsp90 are phosphorylated by Saccharomyces Wee1 (Swe1)/Wee1 tyrosine kinase when Hsp90 is in an open conformation, and phospho-mimetic mutation of these sites promoted kinase loading onto Hsp90.(136) Post-translational modification of Hsp90 plays an important role not only in various biological functions but also effects the sensitivity of the response to Hsp90 inhibitors.(7,137) CK2-mediated phosphorylation of Thr22 on Hsp90 enhanced the affinity of Hsp90 inhibitors, including GDA, STA-9090, and SNX-2112.(136)
    Table 2. Post-translational Sites in Hsp90 Isoforms
    post-translational modificationisoform of Hsp90residueskinases
    phosphorylationHsp90αThr5, Thr7DNA-PK
    phosphorylationHsp90αThr36, Thr65, Thr72, Ser63, Ser68, Ser231, Ser263CK2
    phosphorylationHsp90αTyr38Wee1
    phosphorylationHsp90αThr90, Ser460PKA
    phosphorylationHsp90αTyr309c-Src
    phosphorylationHsp90βThr31, Ser58, Thr60, Ser63, Thr67, Ser226, Ser255CK2
    phosphorylationHsp90βThr85, Ser452PKA
    phosphorylationHsp90βTyr33Wee1
    phosphorylationHsp90βTyr301c-Src
    acetylationHsp90αLys69, Lys100, Lys209, Lys224, Lys292, Lys294, Lys314, Lys356, Lys327, Lys407, Lys478, Lys485, Lys489, Lys546, Lys558, Lys631, Lys632 
    acetylationHsp90βLys64, Lys95, Lys204, Lys219, Lys284, Lys286, Lys306, Lys319, Lys347, Lys399, Lys477, Lys481, Lys538, Lys550, Lys623, Lys624 
    S-nitrosylationHsp90αCys597 
    S-nitrosylationHsp90βCys589 
    oxidationHsp90αCys572 
    oxidationHsp90βCys564 
    Deacetylation of Hsp90 is promoted by histone deacetylases (HDACs). Different isoforms of HDACs affect the chaperone function of Hsp90. Inhibition of HDAC6 was reported to modulate VEGF receptor regulation and immune homeostasis.(138) HDAC1 specifically deacetylates Hsp90 in the nucleus of human breast cancer cells.(139) Rao et al. demonstrated that hyperacetylation of Hsp90 caused by HDAC6 deficiency promoted the binding of 17-AAG to Hsp90,(138) and Robbins et al. reported that acetylation of Lys290 enhanced the sensitivity of Hsp90α to 17-AAG.(140) In addition, S-nitrosylation, which is dependent on nitric oxide (NO), can reversibly modify cysteines in Hsp90αC leading to the inhibition of ATPase activity.(141) This phenomenon suggests crosstalk between the antitumor activity of NO and Hsp90 chaperone function. Tubocapsenolide A (76), a novel withanolide (Figure 21), was shown to increase ROS accumulation and thus trigger thiol oxidation of Hsp90 with client protein degradation.(142) Mahanine (77), a carbazole alkaloid (Figure 21), disrupts the Hsp90-Cdc37 interaction by inducing thiol oxidation of Hsp90.(143) Taken together, these results indicate that posttranslational modification of Hsp90 is a potential strategy for the development of novel Hsp90 inhibitors. Furthermore, the effect of these modifications on the sensitivity of current Hsp90 inhibitors may facilitate research on drug combination therapies. This strategy could allow a decrease in the dose of Hsp90 inhibitors by enhancing their sensitivity to Hsp90, which may reduce severe side effects.

    6. Challenges and Future Perspective

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    6.1. Safety Concerns of Targeting Hsp90 ATPase

    Despite the extensive study of Hsp90N ATP inhibitors, none have been approved by the FDA. The primary limitations of clinical Hsp90 inhibitors can be divided into two aspects: (i) the unacceptable adverse events such as hepatotoxicity and ocular toxicity; and (ii) the unsatisfactory efficiency caused by HSR and drug resistance. For example, a partial response was observed during treatment with SNX-5422 (30) in 1 of 25 patients with myeloma and lymphoma, but investigations were terminated due to ocular toxicity in preclinical and other phase I trials.(144) Consequently, identifying the causes of these unsolved problems related to Hsp90 ATPase inhibitors is necessary. On the one hand, Hsp90 is an abundant cellular protein that performs numerous critical biofunctions, and ATP binding is the basis of the Hsp90 chaperone cycle. Thus, inhibition of Hsp90 by ATPase inhibitors can impair the whole array of client proteins, which may cause unexpected effects on both normal cells and neoplastic cells. On the other hand, different tumor types are sensitive to specific Hsp90-dependent oncoproteins, for instance, Her2 upregulation in breast cancer and ALK accumulation in NSCLC. These examples suggest that not all client proteins of Hsp90 are equally necessary for inhibition. This observation may explain some of the severe side effects of clinical Hsp90 inhibitors. Additionally, a possible mechanism of resistance to Hsp90 ATPase inhibitors has been investigated (Figure 22). First, mutation of the N-terminal nucleotide binding site would alter inhibitor affinity.(145,146) A single mutation, L34I, in Humicola fuscoatra Hsp90 decreased its affinity for radicicol.(146) However, mutations in human cells treated with Hsp90 inhibitors remain unknown. Second, ATPase inhibitors hinder the progression of Hsp90 supercomplexes through the ATP cycle, leading to the free state of the Hsp90-bound transcription factor HSF-1.(147) Zou et al. showed that the Hsp90 multichaperone machinery is a significant repressor of HSF-1.(147) Activated HSF-1 is translocated into the nucleus after phosphorylation and trimerization, which initiates overexpression of Hsp’s, including Hsp27, Hsp40, and Hsp70, to mediate a prosurvival process called the HSR. One characteristic of the HSR is enhancement by Hsp70, which plays a key role in promoting antiapoptotic activity to protect tumor cells.(148) Furthermore, upregulation of Hsp70 was observed in a Western blot assay of tumor cell lysates after treatment with inhibitors of Hsp90 ATPase activity. These effects limit the activity of Hsp90 inhibitors. In contrast, silencing HSF1, Hsp70, or Hsp27 significantly enhanced sensitivity to Hsp90 inhibition. Moreover, SNX-2112 (29) was reported to promote the efflux function of P-glycoprotein (P-gp) pumps at a concentration of 320 nM, but P-gp inhibitors facilitated the intestinal absorption of SNX-2112 (29), with an increase of 3.1- to 14.1-fold.(149) Thus, drug accumulation may be blocked due to the action of ansamycin analogs as stimulators of P-gp, which may narrow the therapeutic window of these inhibitors.(150) Additionally, novel strategies for Hsp90 inhibition with client specificity or isoform selectivity aimed at certain oncogenic functions have been thoroughly researched.
    Hence, these tremendous challenges prevent Hsp90N inhibitors from entering the market. Researchers have attempted to solve these problems. The combination of clinical Hsp90 inhibitors with synergistic agents is a potential strategy to extend the therapeutic window with lower doses. HDACs play a key role in the regulation of oncogenes, and several HDAC inhibitors have been approved by the FDA for cancer treatment. Combinations of Hsp90 and HDAC inhibitors have been widely investigated in preclinical trials. For example, a combination of 17-AAG and HDAC inhibitors, including sodium butyrate (SB), suberoylanilide hydroxamic acid (SAHA), or LBH589, can synergistically induce apoptosis in leukemia cells.(151) Rao et al. demonstrated that silencing of the HDAC6 gene induced hyperacetylation of Hsp90 and enhanced the Hsp90 inhibitory activity of 17-AAG in leukemia cells.(138) On the other hand, the combination of Hsp90 with tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) has been reported as a promising strategy to combat TKIs resistance.(152) Targeting the mutated or excessive receptor tyrosine kinase is a potent therapy in cancer treatment. However, patients usually suffer from TKI resistance after treatment. Studies have shown that Hsp90 inhibitors overcome drug resistance caused by TKIs and many receptor tyrosine kinases are clients of Hsp90, such as ALK, EGFR, Her2, and JAK. Wang et al. summarized the combination therapies of Hsp90 inhibitors and TKIs in detail.(152) ALK and Hsp90 dual inhibitors bearing resorcinol and a 2,4-diaminopyrimidine scaffold have been designed leading to potent activity against H3122 cells.(153) Lee et al. showed that a Hsp90 inhibitor (NVP-AUY922) restored the sensitivity to a PI3K inhibitor (omipalisib) in human NSCLC cell lines and that these two inhibitors have a synergistic effect at a lower concentration.(154)
    Compared with pan-inhibitors of Hsp90 ATPase activity, isoform-selective inhibitors of Hsp90 provide a means to understand the functional discrepancy between Hsp90 isoforms. The client proteins of Hsp90α/β and Grp94 are different from each other. Thus, investigation of potential indications of isoform-selective Hsp90 inhibitors is necessary. Several studies have revealed that Grp94 inhibitors have a positive treatment effect in open angle glaucoma without cytotoxicity to tumor cell lines.(155)

    6.2. Difficulty in Targeting the Highly Dynamic Interactions of Hsp90 and Its Co-chaperones

    Another Hsp90 inhibition strategy is targeting the binding sites of Hsp90 with its co-chaperones. In contrast to Hsp90 ATPase activity inhibitors, Hsp90 PPI inhibitors disrupt Hsp90 functions by selectively downregulating client proteins without affecting the ATPase activity of Hsp90. However, problems also exist in the development of PPI inhibitors targeting Hsp90 and its co-chaperones. For example, the highly dynamic state of the Hsp90-Cdc37 PPI has been proven via crystal structure (PDB: 1US7, PDB: 5FWL). The binding site of Cdc37 was reported to be transferred from Hsp90N to Hsp90 M by the formation of the Hsp90-Cdc37-Cdck4 ternary complex, which revealed that the Hsp90-Cdc37 interaction was highly dynamic.(89) Further, the interaction of Hsp90-Aha1 is also dynamic in the Hsp90 chaperone cycle. The binding sites are distinct from those involved in typical PPIs, which are flatter and more hydrophilic. Hence, this problem provides a big challenge for small molecular inhibitors that anchor the flat binding sites or improve the binding activity to Hsp90. More than 80% of cellular PPIs are non-classical PPIs with flat and dynamic interaction hotspots, rendering the development of small-molecule disruptors challenging. Therefore, the investigation of inhibitors targeting non-classical PPIs is helpful to understand these “difficult” tool molecules to explore the highly dynamic interactions between Hsp90 and co-chaperones.

    6.3. Potential Development of Covalent Inhibitors as an Alternative and Specific Strategy

    The sequence of Hsp90 contains six cysteine residues. Some natural products, such as 46, can disrupt the Hsp90-Cdc37 PPI via a covalent allosteric mechanism. In particular, the covalent bond between Hsp90 and 46 was verified by the mass spectra on Cys420.
